comments.commentBody: Grow up, DJT, act your age.  We'll take senile, but not juvenile.

To be fair, NYTimes: you guys didn't offer any hard evidence when accusing Trump of ties to Russia. Just that sources had said there was something. Still no smoking gun. (Tho many of us would be more than happy to see it)

The NYT does not claim to be the US president. One hopes the bar is higher for presidential behavior--even if the current so-called incumbent consistently succeeds in crawling under that bar.

The circumstantial evidence of the Trump campaign's contacts with Russians grows by the day. Plus the lack of evidence (tax returns) points to the same conclusions.

Another baseless allegation, another media circus brought on by the President's outlandish accusations. And more proof positive that I was right to vote for Hillary Clinton. Donald Trump has confirmed every worst fear I had about him.

To Cynthia ~ I wear with pride a button that states "Don't Blame Me, I Voted for Hillary".
Djt has not only confirmed every worst fear I had about him but has surpassed it. He is much worse than I thought he'd be. He seems certifiable.

If he does not want to act like a President, he should just quit.  It looks like he say or heard some crazy nonsense from Breitbart or some site of comparable credibility, and tweeted an unfounded accusation about the previous President.  This is fine if he is just some blowhard in a bar, but this is not appropriate behavior for the President of the United States

Amazing what an educated and ambitious Kenyan can do in this day and age!  BTW: If this is how we're all set to learn about The Donald's treasonous phone calls to Russian officials during the run-up to the election the ends clearly justify the means. Maybe they'll end up sharing the same prison cell...

Such a great comment.   All of these superhero comics before the 1990s began out of a male teenager fantasy of power.  With lots of fighting.  Everyone is a warrior, etc.  The stories were written by men for male teens with the purpose for them to buy every serialized/illustrated story.  I love the Rand angle and that might be there under the hood (!) but how comics were written and who they appealed to is pretty clear.

Disconcerting article, however, the tone almost implies that North Korea has an arsenal of nuclear weapons that could hit the United States. This is a dubious assumption considering the decrepit economy of North Korea. Therefore, what is the success rate of our missile defense system when n=1? I bet it's a lot higher than 56%.

Diplomacy obviously hasn't worked to slow the advance of this nuclear program, therefore the only endgame I see is regime change through military intervention. (Or we perpetually maintain the status quo until one of my vital organs gives out.) But what happens to North Korea when the world topples it's regime? Does South Korea take care of the millions of brainwashed and impoverished citizens? What a mess that is.
So you would recommend military response to NKorea for acting within its rights, and ..perhaps complain about Russian interference in US elections ?

But imagine if only one, yes one hit somewhere in the US. That would go a long long way towards NK's goal of defeating us. Just imagine that for a moment.
For once they would actually have a reason to fill the airwaves and cyberspace with the incessant shrieking that takes place now.
Imagine the public's fear & the crackdown by our government on our lives. The goal of destroying us would be mostly achieved. If even one came close, most of this would come to pass.

Regime change is a failed US tactic. It didn't work in Iraq, Libya, Afghanistan, Viet Nam, Central America, Cuba, Chile and on and on. It does, however, benefit Weapons of Mass Destruction Manufacturers around the world.

Trump's obsession with being spied on reminds me of the character in the movie The Conversation, Harry Caul, portrayed by Gene Hackman.

Caul is someone who is paid to spy on other people, yet in the end the tables seem to be turned as Caul tears up floorboards and walls, destroying his own apartment in his search for surveillance devices, as he has become obsessed with the idea that it is he who is now being spied upon.

Trump no doubt has a closet packed full of skeletons from his past, as his unruly fear seems disproportionate in his suspecting President Obama of somehow setting up surveillance on him. Perhaps it is The Donald’s own conscience, his own fear of his deep secrets being dug up, that makes our present president so fearful and twitterly obsessed.

DJT 's bizarre tweets are evidence that he remains distracted from the 'big league' task his nascent office must complete before he can ever get up to speed: filling all the jobs the federal government needs to function.  I hear the rumble of a train wreck approaching.

" I hear the rumble of a train wreck approaching." Yes, indeed, Rwh,  the rumble of a train wreck of this country, to be replaced, the Left must hope, by a civil war in this country, culminating in their unchallenged rule (judging by their consistently violent actions, dishonest words, and unprecedented shadow presidency in Washington) .

"lling all the jobs the federal government needs to function"
You forget that the object of this administration is to destroy the federal government.
DT says he doesn't want to fill most of those jobs, that the government can operate lean and mean.

The Intelligence Community needs to have a very serious sit down with Trump & staff. They should explain exactly how they do their work and what is legal for both the Intelligence Community and for the White House. If possible, they need to get commitments from the White House to stop making public claims of bias and illegality.

Then the Intelligence Community needs to decide, going forward, what is the appropriate course of action to protect the country. They need to fully inform Congress of their conversation and the details of all ongoing investigations.

It is way past time to demand that the White House act like grown ups, stop spouting lies and promoting conspiracy theories, and promise to base statements and actions upon verifiable information generated by government agencies.

If the White House cannot trust the government and the Intelligence Community cannot trust the White House, Trump must resign or be impeached. Enough of all this stupidity!

"The Intelligence Community needs to have a very serious sit down with Trump & staff. They should explain exactly how they do their work and what is legal for both the Intelligence Community and for the White House."

I suspect that this has already occurred, and that Trump is angry with McGahn because the WH Counsel told him that no, he can't just order the intelligence community and the Justice Department to stop investigating and bury whatever they've turned up.

Mark Twain once wrote an essay lamenting the sad decline the art of lying. Donald Trump is a very sad confirmation of that decline.His lies are so transparent and poorly thought out you would think they were coming from the mind of a demented six year old.

I actually tweeted Trump recently and said "You're more of a Borscht-belt comedian than a President, aren't you? Very unusual!" This is the funniest yet most defamatory thing he has said yet — but he still has 50 days left to top himself.

Well, it was Mary Ann Williamson, the spiritual guru, who wrote in one of her books, "When I asked God to change me, he sent a wrecking ball"! Guess who OUR wrecking ball is?
Only 50 days left?? If ONLY!

Last week Mr. Trump it seemed was presidential and this week he is not. I think he needs to make up his mind whether he wants to be the president or be held back in middle school.

In seriousness, there is a pattern behind his antics - he is trying to obfuscate other issues that are not in his favor. I do not believe that Mr. Trump expected to be elected. And post election he was not quick to put on a team together to run the country. He is not comfortable with folks whom he does not trust. By having this outlook he is having the second and third level leadership from previous administration run the show. Rather than admit his mistakes he is quick to point to others. He also trusts the right wing radio talk show hosts more than most patriots. Even they, the host, are very good at complaining; now they don't know how to provide support to the President to be able run smoothly. It is easy to spew forth ideas but not easy to execute. It is going to be a very interesting 4 years.

R Nathan--He READ (not very well) a speech, he did not write, promoting the same stupid ideas, without yelling.  That is NOT "presidential," and corporate news sources who say it is, are attempting to not offend any conservative viewers they may have, as well as APPEAR to be "trump-neutral."  They should all grow several pairs.

The only reason Trump appeared presidential is because he was reading a teleprompter. He has a history of lying and blaming anything not going his way on others, and he cannot admit when he is wrong, no matter how obvious. His coaching goes back to his father, his notorious lawyer associate Roy Cohn, and the manner in which he conducted his real estate dealing. When things are going down for Donald Trump, it is everybody else's fault; so you are correct in that we are dealing with a middle school mentality. In order to guarantee a victory in the 2016 election, Mr. Trump used below the belt tactics typical of the Republican party when they have their backs against the wall, but Trump took these tactics to a whole new level. He went so far as to suggest to the Russians to hack email servers, to which they complied and proceeded to let Mr. Trump in on the gig. I can see Trump now dancing a jig reminiscent of Hitler when he was informed of the leaks on the DNC. Now the entire gig is beginning to fall apart as more and more information is coming out, while the Russians are waiting for their favor of having sanctions to be relieved. How is the Donald going to get everyone to listen to him so he can pay off his favor to the Russians? Will the Russian ambassador crack? Will Putin fall off his chair laughing at the ineptitude of Trump and the US? Stay tuned for the continuing episode of "Megalomaniac in the White House!"
PVM--He did not appear presidential.  He is incapable of ever APPEARING presidential.  He's incompetent and a "sick guy."  He's an illegitimate loser.  Never trump.  RESIST!

It's less the charge--which if supported by evidence would be alarming--than his amateur way of handling it.

The man cannot even spell "tap" correctly. Failing to check spelling does not argue well for his impulse control in a crisis.
More chaff to hide what Trump, and other members of Bannon's team, are up to.
He's already got America's most respected journalist, Geraldo Rivera, taking up his case.  No need to put out "fake news" when Geraldo's got your back.

Martin, yes lore is important but writers should have the right to tell the story they want to tell even if it doesnt exactly line up to established lore.  Heck look what Peter Jackson did to The Hobbit.

Donald, you just keep digging the hole deeper and deeper for yourself.  When you make wild accusations with no proof, it just builds on your reputation of being a liar.  Your Russian connection is spiraling out of control like Watergate  because your are covering up.  We all know how this ends- the house voting out articles of impeachment forcing you to resign.

Got started with NIGHTWEAR, ESCHER, YARDSTICK, YPRES, and EMPHASIZE, so the back and forth rolled right along with hairstyles being my first quote breakthrough. I thought it was going to be on the easier side, but I had babySat before OVERSAW and had to make numerous corrections along the way. So it wasn't so easy really. ACETATE, EUREKA, and IRIDESCE came fairly soon (checked the spelling on the latter just to be sure).

The quote was really fun, providing such a variety of words. The roller-derby noms de guerre had me chuckling; we watched it on TV at home when I was a kid. PIE CHART and LEMON PEEL had great clues. Also a new word for me, OPISMATH, was the last to fill in.
Amen...

By one estimate he and his family have already cost taxpayers $97 million.

"By one sketchy estimate, Trump and his family, in their security and travel demands, have already rung up as much in accounts payable by taxpayers as the Obama and Biden families did in eight years, a figure elsewhere calculated, by the Washington DC-based Judicial Watch, as topping $97m."
Read more details: https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/04/donald-trump-travel-cost...

The best thing President Obama can do (and knowing he's an intelligent man he will) is let the child rant, alone, in his own echo chamber.  No reply can do any more damage than our man-child in chief can do to himself, unaided.

Just wait until he does something that wakes you up rather than exhausts you.

And he will. We are in the hands of not only an amateur, but a paranoiac without any impulse control.

Of course Trump is irate that Sessions recused himself.  The reason for Sessions, a corrupt, cut-throat partisan during his US Attorney days in Mobile, according to The Guardian today, was to protect Trump from being investigated for being a Russian mole.  Vlad must be rethinking his alliance with Trump because the orange cretin can't keep his trap shut, coming unglued with every new piece of information coming his way.  Maybe what Putin giveth, Putin taketh away?  Beware of umbrellas, Prez Trump, some of them are not as innocent as they appear.

Trump has the Attorney General, the Director of the FBI, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Director of the National Security Agency, the Director of the CIA, the Secretaries of Defense and Homeland Security and his own Chief of the National Security Council reporting to him.

Did he ask any of them if Breitbart reports sourced to an insane radio conspiracy monger were true?

Of course not.

If it were true, Trump breached national security and recklessly used Twitter to announce a serious matter of national security.

If it is not true, he recklessly again put the nation through a fake crisis just to deflect attention from serious inquiries.

In either case, Trump was grossly unhinged. He is unable to responsibly exercise the duties of his office and must be replaced under the Constitution.

Will it require a nuclear war launched for no valid reason for Republicans to take responsibility?
